newsitem.title: USA: Kaczynski wins round in challenge to cabin search.
newsitem.headline: Kaczynski wins round in challenge to cabin search.

text.p: A U.S. magistrate on Tuesday ordered prosecutors to turn over a key document to Unabomber suspect Theodore Kaczynski's lawyers, who have asked the court to throw out evidence against their client.

In a partial victory for the defence team, U.S. Magistrate Gregory Hollows at a hearing in Sacramento granted Kaczynski's requests for a government document about the search of his cabin, and opened the door for broader discovery by his lawyers, who are challenging physical evidence that allegedly incriminates the former mathematics professor.

Hollows said the defence could have a copy of the partial draft of the original search warrant affidavit for Kaczynski's remote Montana cabin. Federal investigators used the final affidavit to obtain a search warrant to enter the cabin.

In addition, Hollows said he would review certain other documents not yet turned over to the defence. These documents include reports and files about 12 people that the defence alleges were other "serious" suspects in the FBI's Unabomber investigation, as well as documents about DNA evidence.
After studying these documents, Hollows said he would decide whether any should be released to the defence.
The defence has asked the court to throw out all of the evidence seized by the FBI at Kaczynski's Montana cabin in April last year.
The defence alleges that the search was illegal because the FBI's affidavit supporting its request for a search warrant contained misleading information.

Kaczynski, 54, was arrested in April 1996 at his rustic one-room cabin in Montana. He is accused of being the shadowy Unabomber, who killed three people and injured 23 during an anti-technology bombing campaign between 1978 and 1995.

Prosecutors and investigators have said they found extensive evidence at the cabin incriminating Kaczynski, including bomb components and a diary that they say contained his "detailed admission" about the Unabomber attacks.
At Tuesday's court hearing, prosecutors argued that the defence had already received all of the documents that they are entitled to.
Kaczynski has been charged in Sacramento with four bombings, two of them deadly. Kaczynski, who is being held in Sacramento, has pleaded not guilty.
His trial is scheduled to start in November.
